NewsLines.HeadLine: U.S. stocks slump; Dow, Nasdaq down more than 1 pct

NewsLine.NewsLineText: MARKETS-USA-STOCKS (UPDATE 3):U.S. stocks slump; Dow, Nasdaq down more than 1 pct

body.p: NEW YORK, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Stocks fell early on Monday in a market spooked by dim outlooks from companies like telecom gear maker JDS Uniphase Corp. and retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and a spike in oil prices fueled by fears of war with Iraq.
"The mood is very nervous," said Edgar Peters, chief investment officer at PanAgora Asset Management, which manages $13 billion.

The technology-laced Nasdaq Composite Index lost 17 points, or 1.40 percent, to 1,203, nearing its five-year low of 1,192.42 hit in July. The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average sank 85 points, or 1.07 percent, to 7,900. The broader Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 8 points, or 0.95 percent, to 837.

JDS, the world's top supplier of components and modules that boost the speed and capacity of optical networks, added its voice to the chorus of companies hurt by sharp slowdown in the telecommunications market. JDS fell 8 cents to $2.06 after trimming its first-quarter sales guidance.

Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, added more pressure to the market with a $1.50 drop to $53.20. The Dow member said it expects September sales at stores open at least a year to come in near the low end of its growth forecast. Home improvement retailer Home Depot Inc. fell $1.09 to $30.14, adding more pressure to the Dow.

The threat of a second Gulf War added to Wall Street's cloud of worries. Iraq vowed on Saturday to reject any new Security Council resolution differing from an agreement reached with the U.N. secretary-general, while President George W. Bush reviewed detailed military options devised by the Pentagon for a possible attack on Iraq.

Oil prices surged with dealers pointing to Baghdad's decision to reject any new U.N. resolution as well as Israel's siege of Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's Ramallah headquarters. Sustained tension in the Middle East, which pumps a third of the world's crude oil, has already driven oil prices up 50 percent this year.

Tyco International fell 54 cents to $14.42 and ranked as the most active on the New York Stock Exchange. Though Tyco's board has said it was unaware of extravagant pay and loans given to top executives, minutes of the board's compensation committee show it knew of many of the payments months before the board took steps to disclose them, The New York Times reported.

Microsoft Corp. fell $1.25 to $46.25 and weighed on the Dow. Soundview Technology Group said the software giant is expensive and it will be difficult for Microsoft to show significant additional growth without a return in personal computer growth and information technology spending.

Dole Food Co., the world's largest producer of fresh fruits, emerged as a bright spot in the market with a $5.96 jump to $30.45. The company's chief executive offered to take Dole private with a $1.26 billion cash bid.
